display_title.display_title:
The assessment, removal, and
            disposal of obsolete pesticides, and the remediation of
            storage sites in the seven countries in Africa, within the
            framework of the Africa Stockpiles Program Project, will
            have considerable, positive environmental and social
            impacts. However, inherent in the project process, are
            unique environmental and social risks, identified in the
            Environmental Management Plan (EMP), which form the basis
            for the following mitigation measures. All participating
            countries are signatories of the Stockholm, Basel and
            Rotterdam Conventions, and each country program is based on
            multi-sectoral national steering committees, in close
            liaison with the technical support unit. The highest
            standards of vessel safety, and security will be ensured to
            minimize catastrophic accidents, i.e., breakup of container
            vessels carrying hazardous materials. Handling of obsolete
            pesticides inventories shall be conducted by trained staff
            in accordance with standard environmental practices, who
            should in turn, be protected from human health hazards with
            appropriate gear and equipment. Pesticide removal and
            clean-up shall be in compliance with standard planning, and
            procedures. Each country's institutional and legal
            framework should establish and enforce legislation and
            standards to support implementation of the project, through
            effective regulatory management processes. In addition, risk
            assessment shall be conducted in a defined and consistent
            manner, a process by which priorities will be assigned for
            the clean-up of sites at the second stage. Monitoring
            criteria will be in place to ensure compliance with this
            EMP, by measuring effectiveness of mitigation under the
            second stage, taking into consideration specific country
            environmental elements (i.e., economic value of land,
            agricultural production, water supplies, cultural heritage
            sites, biodiversity, among others). (Vol. 5) : Résumé analytique
